channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Crowd Crush is Seoul Was Like a ‘Tsunami Wave’
item.description: A witness described the force of the crowd pushing him back and forth near the scene of the disaster.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur
item.media:description: People after being rescued at the scene where scores of people were killed and dozens were injured in a crowd crush in Seoul.

item.title: With Western Weapons, Ukraine Is Turning the Tables in an Artillery War
item.description: In the southern Kherson region, Ukraine now has the advantage in range and precision guidance of artillery, rockets and drones, erasing what had been a critical Russian asset.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A team of Ukrainian soldiers armed a drone with bombs on Friday during a mission that destroyed a Russian armored personnel carrier on the front lines in the country’s southern Kherson region.

item.title: Elon Musk Is Said to Have Ordered Job Cuts Across Twitter
item.description: The billionaire planned to begin layoffs as soon as Saturday, people with knowledge of the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger, Ryan Mac, Sheera Frenkel and Mike Isaac
item.media:description: Twitter’s headquarters in San Francisco. Layoffs had been expected and feared by Twitter employees.

item.title: Silicon Valley’s Unbridled Euphoria Runs Into Economic Reality
item.description: Once-buzzy start-ups had held out against the new reality that the good times are over. No longer.
item.dc:creator: Erin Griffith

item.title: Pelosi Attack Highlights Rising Fears of Political Violence
item.description: The assault of the House speaker’s husband inside their home comes as threats against members of Congress have increased in recent years.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: Security personnel standing guard while Representative Steve Scalise, Republican of Louisiana, was speaking on the steps of the Capitol last year. Mr. Scalise was shot in 2017 by a man with a grudge against Republicans.

item.title: Attack on Nancy Pelosi’s Husband, Paul Pelosi: What We Know
item.description: Paul Pelosi, 82, underwent surgery for a skull fracture after he was assaulted at the couple’s home in San Francisco, and was expected to recover, a spokesman for Ms. Pelosi said.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch

item.title: Governor’s Races Enter Final Sprint on a Scrambled, Surprising Map
item.description: Deep-red Oklahoma is in play for Democrats. New York and Oregon are within reach for Republicans. And several swing states have tight races with high stakes on abortion, elections and other issues.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Barack Obama campaigned in Georgia on Friday for Stacey Abrams, the Democratic nominee for governor, and Senator Raphael Warnock.

item.title: Brazil Confronts a Momentous Bolsonaro vs. Lula Election
item.description: Brazilians head to the polls on Sunday in an election between two political heavyweights that could have global repercussions.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brazil’s far-right president, Jair Bolsonaro, is seeking a second term as he faces off against a leftist opponent and a former president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva.

item.title: Bolsonaro vs. Lula: What to Know About Brazil’s Runoff Election
item.description: The vote comes after a long and ugly campaign that pits two major political figures against each other in race that has tested the country’s democracy.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voting in the first round of presidential elections earlier this month in São Paulo.

item.title: World Series: Framber Valdez and Astros Even Series With Game 2 Win
item.description: Houston set the tone against Philadelphia with three straight hits to start Game 2, giving Framber Valdez and the Astros bullpen all the support they needed for a big win at home.
item.dc:creator: Scott Miller
item.media:credit: Annie Mulligan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jose Altuve started Game 2 by doubling on the first pitch he saw. The struggling second baseman finished the day with three hits.

item.title: Canceled Day of When We Were Young Festival Left ‘a Lot of Sad Emos’
item.description: The When We Were Young festival in Las Vegas brought emo fans from all over the world to one destination. But when weather got in the way, they mourned together.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Aggeler
item.media:credit: Saeed Rahbaran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jessica Gems, left, and Amanda Fulton traveled to Las Vegas from New York to attend the festival.

item.title: The Pelosis and a Haunted America
item.description: Gruesome Republicans are writing our national horror story.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.media:description: Nancy and Paul Pelosi in 1987. They have been married for 59 years.

item.title: Don’t Buy the Republican Appeal to Workers
item.description: For ordinary workers, living paycheck to paycheck, the G.O.P. is AWOL.
item.dc:creator: Terri Gerstein
item.media:credit: Brian Kaiser for The New York Times
item.media:description: J.D. Vance, left, speaking at a Republican event this month.

item.title: Affirmative Action Has Become a Strange Monster
item.description: An admissions system that made sense as reparations has survived as something much more self-serving.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat

item.title: The Political Power of Gas Prices and More: The Week in Narrated Articles
item.description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.

item.title: A Zuni Café Classic Without the Chicken? It’s Possible.
item.description: Try a warm bread salad with crisp mushrooms, inspired by the restaurant dish.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao

item.title: How Horror Stories Help Us Cope With Real Life
item.description: Scary movies, books and podcasts can help people think through how they would respond to threats and prepare them for worst-case scenarios, say experts who study the psychology of fear.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer

item.title: Do You Have Messy Handwriting? We Want to See It.
item.description: Is your penmanship a mess? Can you often not read your own handwriting? Share something you wrote and later found hard to decipher.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Paoletto

item.title: An ‘Army’ of Volunteer Sleuths Are Out Hunting for Your Stolen Car
item.description: In Portland, Ore., vehicle thefts have soared, and the police say they are focused on other crimes. Now victims are helping each other track down their own cars.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker
item.media:credit: Justin Katigbak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Titan Crawford has led a growing network of volunteer sleuths who scour Portland’s streets, alleys and forests, racing against time in hopes of finding stolen vehicles before they end up shredded for parts.

item.title: Sacheen Littlefeather and the Question of Native Identity
item.description: The actress, who died Oct. 2, became famous for a protest at the 1973 Oscars. Now a researcher and Littlefeather’s own sisters dispute her claims that she was Native American. Her defenders say Indian identity is a complex matter.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina and Michael Levenson
item.category: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences
item.media:description: Sacheen Littlefeather at an event in September in her honor at the Academy Museum in Los Angeles. She was joined by Bird Runningwater, the co-chairman of the Academy’s Indigenous Alliance.

item.title: Portland Thorns Win NWSL Championship to End Turbulent Season
item.description: Portland won its third championship in the league’s 10th season, in a year of upheaval amid an abuse scandal in the sport.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.media:description: The Portland Thorns took an early lead and dominated the ball in their victory over the Kansas City Current, 2-0.

item.title: House-Hunting for Caves on Mars Has Already Started
item.description: Researchers identified nine caves on the red planet that might make suitable shelters for future astronauts.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Kornei
item.media:description: A detail of the Deuteronilus Mensae region of Mars where researchers on Earth found a number of caves that could be suitable dwellings for future human visitors.

item.title: RSV: What to Know About Symptoms, Transmission and Treatment
item.description: Before the Covid pandemic, most people caught respiratory syncytial virus before the age of 2. Now things have changed.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh

item.title: How to Stay Sane About Halloween Candy
item.description: No, your children won’t overload on peanut butter cups. Yes, you can eat their mini Snickers.
item.dc:creator: Virginia Sole-Smith

item.title: Covid Symptoms Can Rebound Even If You Don’t Take Paxlovid
item.description: A new study found that more than a third of those who recovered from an infection had symptoms recur days or weeks later.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.category: Journal of the American Medical Assn
item.media:description: Rebound symptoms are common, said one doctor. “It doesn’t mean that things are going south,” he said. “It’s just the natural way the disease goes.”

item.title: Please Let Me Terrify Some Kids on Halloween
item.description: A socially distanced dad hopes that frightening children isn’t a thing of the past.
item.dc:creator: Erik Vance

item.title: ‘Oh, I’ll Show You’: Paul Taylor and Alex Katz’s Long Collaboration
item.description: There were egos and clashes, but the choreographer and painter made 16 dances together over more than 50 years, work spotlighted in the Taylor company’s season.
item.dc:creator: Brian Seibert
item.media:credit: Julieta Cervantes for The New York Times
item.media:description: Eran Bugge and fellow dancers rehearsing “Diggity,” one of four classic Paul Taylor-Alex Katz collaborations to be featured during the Paul Taylor Dance Company’s two-week season at Lincoln Center.

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
